keyTakeAways: Virginia Giuffre, a former victim of Jeffrey Epstein’s sex-trafficking ring, claims in her posthumous memoir that she was raped by a 'well-known Prime Minister' — a reference widely interpreted as Prince Andrew in the US version.
The memoir claims Giuffre was beaten, choked, and humiliated during her time with Epstein, describing one instance where the man laughed and became aroused during her abuse.
In the UK version of the memoir, the man is referred to as a 'former minister,' creating a discrepancy that has sparked debate about the accuracy and translation of the narrative.

Giuffre alleges that Prince Andrew, despite claiming never to have met her, was involved in sexual encounters with her when she was 17, and that he paid millions to settle a civil case against him in 2022.
Andrew’s legal team reportedly attempted to hire online trolls to discredit Giuffre during her civil case, and a UK newspaper reported he asked a bodyguard to dig up dirt on her in 2011.
Newly unearthed emails show that Prince Andrew continued to communicate with Epstein in February 2011, directly contradicting his public claim that he had ended their relationship in December 2010.
The memoir intensifies existing transatlantic scrutiny over powerful individuals' proximity to Epstein, with the royal family facing renewed public backlash.
Prince Andrew has since relinquished the title of Duke of York, but will retain the title of Prince, stating he prioritizes family and national duty.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Virginia Giuffre, a victim of Jeffrey Epstein’s sex-trafficking ring, published a posthumous memoir alleging that she was raped by a man she described as a 'well-known Prime Minister' — widely interpreted as Prince Andrew — during her teenage years. The memoir claims the abuse involved choking, beating, and psychological torture, with the perpetrator laughing during the assault and becoming aroused. Giuffre alleges that Prince Andrew, despite denying any contact, maintained ties with Epstein and paid millions to settle a civil case. The article highlights that Prince Andrew's public claims of severing ties with Epstein are contradicted by emails showing continued contact in 2011. It also reveals that Andrew’s team reportedly tried to hire online trolls to discredit Giuffre and that the Metropolitan Police are investigating a report that Andrew asked a bodyguard to dig up dirt on her. These revelations intensify a transatlantic scandal surrounding powerful figures' connections to Epstein and deepen the disgrace surrounding Prince Andrew, who has since stepped down from using the title Duke of York but retained the title Prince.
